ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to develop a focused research question, use tools like Zotero and the Poorvu Center's resources, how to write about and think critically about films.
Doing independent research and overcoming obstacles along the way.

Learned how to start from scratch and build an independent research project: choosing topics, research methods, group support sessions, writing, etc. Students come from diverse backgrounds so the topics are so different and interesting.

Interdisciplinary research skills: interviewing, creating data tables and charts, maps, analyzing text, etc. Peer work and working with a writing tutor to polish the final essay was a nice touch as well!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Camille is the most enthusiastic and committed professor that I have met at Yale. She is so dedicated to this class and her students. Each class she would bring tea and snacks, and you could tell that each class session was meticulously planned to benefit our research and writing process. The small class size was great because we were able to get to know each others' projects throughout the semester. Freedom of topic choice was also great--you could truly choose anything to write about--and allowed students to enjoy what they were doing, since they personally chose topics. I enjoyed the space that she gave us with deadlines, trusting us to fill in the semester with work, but also that she was flexible when needed.
No weaknesses! In fact, I cannot think of a way to be improved, because it was basically perfect.
Wonderful and kind professor, and I really enjoyed the seminar format of the classroom where students could seek inspiration from other students.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! If you have the drive to complete an independent writing/research project like this class asks of you, absolutely take this class even if you're not a film major! Our class had a wonderful variety of majors and interests, which worked really well because we all had very unique projects that we were able to learn from each other about. Camille is the perfect person to guide you through the process, and the deadlines are fairly hands-off--the class offers so many resources, but it's up to you to ask for help when you need it. Feedback on assignments was always quick, detailed, and actually helpful in improving my writing. I always looked forward to attending class each week.
Absolutely! Do yourself a favor and take it before you graduate.

YES! Camille is one of my favorite professors at Yale, extremely sweet, supportive, understanding and inspirational. You learn so much from each class and theres always new surprises. You walk out of the course feeling more confident about yourself as a thinker, writer, and researcher.

Absolutely, Camille spends so much time to create an inspirational environment for all of us writers. I am a big fan of the interdisciplinary nature of the course so I was able to learn how to create maps/timelines/charts, to interview, to explore the Movie Memory Archive, to synthesize human experiences, balancing quantitative and qualitative skills.
